awd_abstract_narration:
Naked mole-rats are unusual because they combine a subterranean lifestyle with living in large colonies. With many animals breathing the same stale air, oxygen supplies become low. Consistent with this, naked mole-rats are extremely tolerant to oxygen deprivation. Their brain is resistant to the effects of oxygen deprivation. The goal of the project is to identify the underlying physiological and genetic factors that give the naked mole-rat its tolerance. This will be important for understanding the diverse ways that animals can change to fit their environment. It will also be important for identifying new ways of surviving oxygen deprivation, which happens in the brain of a human who suffers a heart attack. Blood can no longer carry oxygen to the brain when the heart fails. The project also includes training graduate and undergraduate students to be scientists. Project staff will interact with the public at a free city zoo to inform people about the interesting biology of the naked mole-rat.

The problem to be studied is, how do naked mole-rats achieve extreme brain tolerance to oxygen deprivation? This will be studied using physiological, biochemical, and genetic techniques. Physiological approaches will include recording electroencephalograms (EEG) and quantifying metabolites related to anaerobic metabolism in animals exposed to hypoxia. The project will also use hippocampal brain slices to measure age-related changes in basic synaptic phenomena including long-term potentiation and long-term depression. Mass spectrometry will be used to determine the functionality (phosphorylation dynamics) of phosphorylation sites on hypoxia-induced programed cell death pathways. Finally, CRISPR/cas9 techniques will be used to produce both cell lines and mutant mice that carry naked mole-rat mutations in hypoxia-induced programed cell death pathways. The results are expected to reveal new ways of establishing brain protection from oxygen deprivation.

por.por_cntn:
A. Overview 

Work from the project has introduced the naked mole-rat as an exciting new model system to study the evolution of the nervous system and behavior. With the support of the NSF, we have identified several unique specializations of nervous system structure and function that appear to be adaptations for the extraordinary habitat and lifestyle of these mammals. Equally important, we have found that the peculiarities of naked mole-rats strike chords of interest with undergraduate students, graduate students, and the general public. We will continue to exploit this interest by employing these animals in undergraduate lab classes and doctoral thesis work, discussions with curious visitors to the local zoo exhibit, and in scientific articles and interviews for mass media outlets.

B. Intellectual Merit

 Under the previous grant, we made several contributions to multiple scientific fields, all connected by their relationship to the naked mole-rat's unique biology. Prior to the project we discovered that the naked mole-rat was the first known mammal that does not feel pain from acid or hot chili peppers. During the project, we identified additional African subterranean species with similar pain insensitivities. We also found that during oxygen deprivation, naked mole-rats go into a very low energy state, similar to hibernation, where their respiration rate, heart rate, and brain activity slow way down. We also completed studies on hearing in this species. We found that naked mole-rats and their relatives, Damaraland mole-rats, have mutations in their cochlear hair cell genes that effectively make them hard of hearing. But, they vocalize quite loudly, and their calls travel well through their tunnels. Finally, we investigated the unique metabolism of the naked mole-rat under oxygen deprivation that began with our discovery that fructose can be utilized to bypass the hypoxic block on glucose passage in glycolysis. We performed metabolomic and genetic analyses of heart, lung, and brain tissues for 52 metabolites under oxygen deprivation. With this large dataset, we were able to show that there is organ-specific reprogramming that occurs during oxygen deprivation whereby differential gene expression and metabolite profiles are seen in the lung as opposed to the heart. This result suggests that when oxygen is scarce, the lung can be reprogrammed to provide energy to the heart when needed.

C. Broader Impacts

Student Mentoring: During the previous grant period in the Park lab, we mentored 6 graduate students (4 women), 21 undergraduate students (including 18 women and 11 underrepresented minorities), and 2 high school students. Two PhDs were conferred. In the Cologna lab, we mentored 9 undergraduates for research (3 of which were underrepresented minorities) and 7 graduate students. Of those mentored, undergraduates received 14 awards, graduate students received 15 awards, and 2 PhDs were conferred. Teaching: We used naked mole-rats in laboratory exercises in undergraduate classes each year and for independent undergraduate research projects associated with classes. We discussed aspects of naked mole-rat neurobiology and research in lectures for 5 classes ranging from first year undergraduates to graduate students. Local Student Outreach: We worked to recruit Chicago-area high schoolers for summer research experiences. Our graduate students volunteered for Expanding Your Horizons, a STEM conference for female middle school students, UIC Chemistry Demo Day for elementary students, and UIC Women in Engineering Summer Program for female high school students. University Service: Our graduate students organized, gave presentations at, and acted as judges for the UIC Neuroscience Conference and Chemistry Research Symposium and also helped recruit students to UIC graduate programs. Our graduate students and Dr. Park also co-organized weekly neurobiology research group seminars. Dr. Cologna is a faculty advisor for the Chemistry Graduate Student Association and organized the annual Chicago Mass Spectrometry Day. Public Outreach: We engaged the general public on Saturday mornings as information specialist volunteers at the free-admission Zoo in Chicago (Lincoln Park Zoo) where we used the naked mole-rat display as a platform to interact with the public, and to discuss the unusual neurobiology of this species.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2023
Modified by: Thomas J Park

Image
  • Naked mole-rats are mouse size rodents that live underground in Africa. They have no fur, are very social, and their large teeth protrude outside of their mouth.
    Victoria Landau, undergraduate.
    Public Domain
    Thomas J Park
    Naked mole-rats at the University of Illinois at Chicago
